author: bridge-bot
content: <ladislaus0x> I'm not sure if I fully understood the idea around "throwing away" the overwhelming amount data of a PK and retain just minimal seed data to still be able to sign with. Is this something we consider due to special constraints in local devnet environments or is this technique supposed to be applied more broadly eventually?

author: bridge-bot
content:
<justindrake> re: **@ladislaus0x**
> I'm not sure if I fully understood the idea around "throwing away" the overwhelming amount data of a PK and retain just minimal seed data to still be able to sign with. Is this something we consider due to special constraints in local devnet environments or is this technique supposed to be applied more broadly eventually?
IMO it may make sense to apply this trick more broadly. If someone is attesting from a weak device (e.g. a Raspberry Pi) then it suffices to store the seed plus a "slice" of the Merkle tree. The height of the slice is parametrisable, but somewhere in the middle (i.e. half way between the leaves and the root) probably gives a good tradeoff between storage and key rederivation latency.
